docs.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of Medicare beneficiaries were left in the lurch by health maintenance organizations pulling out of the program. Some elderly and disabled patients have enrolled in other H.M.O.'s. Many returned to Medicare's fee-for-service program, but lost prescription benefits and cannot easily afford private insurance to fill the gaps.

headline.main: Dec. 31 - Jan. 6; Health Care Losses and Gains

docs.lead_paragraph: Pope John Paul II pulled shut the Holy Door to St. Peter's today, marking the end of a Holy Year that brought millions of Roman Catholic pilgrims to Rome and took the 80-year-old pope to Jerusalem to pray at the Western Wall, Judaism's holiest site. Today's ceremony was simpler than the elaborate ritual surrounding the opening of the door on Christmas Eve, but the pope seemed just as rapt, and in some ways a little stronger than a year ago, when two aides had to support him for part of the ceremony. A cardinal kept a guiding hand on the pope's elbow, but the pope delivered his homily to an estimated 100,000 people in St. Peter's Square in a clear, strong voice. He was able to kneel before the bronze panels of the Holy Door without assistance, and after the Mass, visibly delighted, drove through cheering crowds in an open papal jeep, waving and kissing babies held up to him.

headline.main: Looking Fit, the Pope Wraps Up a Momentous Holy Year

docs.abstract: Pope John Paul II shuts Holy Door to St Peter's Basillica, marking end of Holy Year; article recounts accomplishments of John Paul during past year; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: PRESIDENT-ELECT GEORGE W. BUSH spent much of last week building support for his tax-cut plan, meeting here with like-minded business executives and asserting that a dose of fiscal stimulus would neatly complement the Federal Reserve's surprise interest rate reduction in the effort to reverse the economy's downturn. But while the incoming administration and its allies in Congress were busy peddling the $1.6 trillion tax cut as anti-recession insurance, conservatives also had their eyes on an even bigger ideological prize.

headline.main: The Nation; The High-Stakes Politics Of Spending the Surplus

docs.abstract: Pres-elect Bush's tax-cut plan would, if enacted, wipe out good portion of projected budget surplus, which would put Congress back in Reagan-era position of having to weigh every spending initiative against keeping budget balanced; photo of Bush with Alan Greenspan (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: One thing is already clear about how President-elect George W. Bush intends to govern the nation: state and local officials will have far more leeway to shape and operate the full range of federal social, regulatory and public works programs. Across the spectrum of domestic policy issues, from health and welfare to education, transportation and environmental protection, the new administration promises to shift power from the federal government to the states, and state officials of both parties said they expected the promises to be kept.

headline.main: SHIFTING OF POWER FROM WASHINGTON IS SEEN UNDER BUSH

docs.abstract: Bush administration promises to shift power in domestic issues from federal government to states; several cabinet and White House staff appointments are filled by people who have had extensive experience at state level and reflect commitment to give states more leeway to run programs and spend federal money as they see fit; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: LIKE many people in their late 50's and early 60's, Jim Langdon, an editor at The Houston Chronicle, wants to retire early to pursue other interests. The trouble is, he can't. Not because he doesn't have a sufficient pension or savings, but because his employer doesn't provide medical insurance benefits to its retirees. Mr. Langdon, who is 59, said he couldn't afford health insurance on his own -- and he isn't eligible for Medicare until he's 65.
docs.abstract: Fred Brock Seniority column on scarcity of health insurance benefits for early retirees, which is forcing many people to defer retirement until they are eligibile for Medicare; holds quick resolution to problem is unlikely; cites federal catastrophic health insurance plan Congress rejected in 1970's as possible solution; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Thousands of the Romanian children who contracted the virus that causes AIDS from needless blood transfusions a decade ago are still alive, but hundreds are now at risk of dying rapidly because they can no longer get the medicine they need. The high prices charged by Western drug companies, Romania's deep poverty and the failures of the country's weak governments have ensured that life-saving anti-retroviral drugs are beyond the reach of many of the children infected in the dying days or aftermath of the despotic rule of Nicolae Ceausescu, who was overthrown and executed in December 1989. Hospitals, crippled by recent bungling of the national health budget, are taking children off their $10,000-a-year AIDS cocktails. Nor can the hospitals afford another estimated $10,000 a year per child for laboratory tests and the best drugs for secondary infections. American and European drug companies, doctors say, have largely declined their requests for cheaper drugs, and the government has so far proved incapable of forcing prices down, or managing budgets to afford the drugs.

headline.main: Romania's AIDS Children: A Lifeline Lost

docs.abstract: Hundreds of Romanian children who contracted AIDS virus ten years ago are at risk of dying because they can no longer get medication they need; high prices charged by Western drug companies combined with deep poverty keep drugs out of reach for hospitals financially crippled by recent bungling of national health budget; American and European drug companies have declined Romania's pleas for cheaper drugs and government has been unable to force prices down; donations of medicine and money are sporadic; children with AIDS are outcast in hospitals and often live in small apartment orphanages bedcause their families cannot care for them or afford drug therapies; photos; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN is a disease rare enough to require a medical specialist outside an insurance network? The answer is less obvious than one might believe. While tonsillitis in even the smallest town could be treated by the local doctor, Ebola virus in Manhattan would clearly require some extremely specialized advice.
docs.abstract: Jennifer Steinhauer column on resolving disputes over whether patient's disease is rare enough to require insurance network to pay for outside specialist; details case in which Oxford Health Plans refused to pay for outside specialist for member Joseph Burke; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: John Vliet Lindsay, the mayor of New York City from 1966 to 1973, who died at the age of 79 on Dec. 19, was never what he appeared to be. He looked rich, but he wasn't. He also looked smarter than he actually was. He seemed the most vulnerable and accessible of men walking the mean streets of his time, but that was an act -- a noble act, but still an act. He was a cool and distant man, the kind who could understand wit but not humor. He was the ultimate WASP, and he proved it by insisting that the acronym should be ASP because all Anglo-Saxons are white. He looked young, healthy and handsome beyond reason, but his body betrayed him in the cruelest ways. He seemed to have it all. The line of graffiti I remember from a train on the Broadway line read, ''John Lindsay is the Lindbergh baby'' -- which set him up for an American tragedy.

headline.main: The Lives They Lived: 01-07-01: John V. Lindsay, b. 1921: Pierre Elliott Trudeau, b. 1919; When Charisma Was King

docs.abstract: Richard Reeves essay pays tribute to John V Lindsay, mayor of New York City from 1966 to 1973, and Pierre Eliott Trudeau, former prime minister of Canada, both of whom died last year; says both had charisma and both showed that glamour can be more powerful political force than mere competence; photos (M)
